module.p: mòran a lot, many, much is a masculine generic quantity noun, expressing a large quantity. It is derived from the adjective mòr big, large using the suffix -an, and has the genitive forms mòrain and mhòran.

section.p: Like other generic quantity nouns, mòran characteristically occurs in three different kinds of grammatical construction.

On its own –
Dh’ith Mairead mòran. Margaret ate a lot.
Tha mòran aig Seumas. James has a lot.
Ach bha eagal air gun cuireadh sin Ealasaid na teine agus cha robh mòran na shaoghal na bu phrìseil’ na an t-eathar.
But he was afraid that that would set fire to Elizabeth and there was not much in his world that was more valuable than the boat. td. 100
Ach tha mi coimhead gu bheil an treubh seo bochd is acrach ’s nach eil mòran as urrainn dhomh a dhèanamh air an son.
But I can see that this tribe is poor and hungry and there is not much I can do for them. td. 20 ‘coimhead’ instead of ‘faicinn’ is a dialectal feature specific to Point in Lewis.
am beachd mòrain
in the opinion of many td. 439

With a genitive modifier –
Dh’òl Raonaid mòran uisge. Rachel drank a lot of water.
Tha mòran chon aig Màiri. Mary has a lot of dogs.
Mu dheireadh fhuair e beairt ’s bha i aige shìos anns an t-sabhal ’s bhiodh e cluich oirre shìos an sin, ged nach robh e dèanamh móran airgid aiste.
Eventually he got a loom and he had it down in the barn and he would be playing with it down there, even though he wasn’t making much money from it. td. 75
Mar a bha nàdarrach, ’s ann aice a dh’fhàg an Caiptean an taigh, agus mòran earrannan ann an dà chompanaidh.
As was natural, the Captain left the house to her, and a lot of shares in two companies. td. 43
“Tha iad ag iarraidh air mòran iseanan a chur thuca, oir tha anaman nan nàimhdean a’ sgiathalaich air falbh don adhar nuair a dh’fhàgas iad an cuirp.”
“They are asking for lots of chicks to be sent to them, because the souls of the enemies are flying away to the sky when they leave their bodies.” td. 54
Bha e air leth modhail, a’ toirt ‘Sir’ dhomh glè thric. Chan eil mòran de dhaoine òga a bheir urram dhan aois an-diugh.
He was exceptionally polite, addressing me as ‘Sir’ frequently. There are not many young people who pay respect to age today. td. 48 Note the use of the preposition de here, rather than a simple genitive.
Ann an Dùn Èideann anns na naochadan bha barrachd agus barrachd inbhich airson Gàidhlig ionnsachadh agus ged a nochd mòran chlasaichean agus cùrsaichean Gàidhlig airson iarrtasan nan daoine sin a fhreagradh, bha ionnsachadh na Gàidhlig ga bhacadh gu mòr air sgàth dìth shuidheachaidhean far an cluinnear an cànan ga bruidhinn gu nàdarra.
In Edinburgh in the 90s there were more and more people wanting to learn Gaelic and although a lot of Gaelic classes and courses sprang up to respond to the demands of those people, Gaelic learning was largely inhibited because of lack of situations where one could hear the language spoken naturally. td. 85

The preposition de with a definite noun –
Chleachd Iain mòran den ìm. John used a lot [too much?] of the butter.
Leugh Mairead mòran de mo leabhraichean. Margaret read a lot of my books.
Bha e ’na sheòladair uair mar a bha móran do’n fheadhainn a th’ anns a’ bhaile [...]
He had been a sailor at one time as had many of those who were in the village [...] td. 100
Gu mì-fhortanach dhaibhsan, bha litrichean na h-aibidil air mòran dhe na fàdan.
Unfortunately for them, there were letters of the alphabet on many of the peats. td. 74
Bha mòran de seo air a chur an cèill le ...
Much of this was expressed by ... td. 439

With a prepositional pronoun –
Dh’òl Raonaid mòran dheth. Rachel drank a lot of it.
Tha mòran dhiubh aig Màiri. Mary has a lot of them.
Thàinig sgrios air sluagh an eilein le breac, uair no dhà, is an 1856 chaidh 35 thairis gu Astràlia ach gu mì-fhortunach chailleadh móran diubh air an t-slighe null le tinneas.
The island’s population was destroyed by smallpox, once or twice, and in 1856 35 went over to Australia but unfortunately many of them were lost on the voyage due to sickness. td. 15
mòran aca
many of them td. 273 Note the use of aca at them rather than dhiubh of them here.

mòran mu a lot [of information/knowledge] about –
Tha Màiri ag iarraidh mòran a chluinntinn mu choin. Mary wants to hear a lot about dogs.
Tha e ag innse mòran mu dheidhinn a’ ghille mar a thachair seo.
It says a lot about the boy how this happened. td. 25
Tha so a’ teagasg móran dhuinn mu Khierkegaard, duine ciogailteach, ro-mhothachail, taghte le gibht a tharraing deuchainnean gun sgur mu a cheann.
This teaches us a lot about Kierkegaard, a difficult, oversensitive man, with a gift for endlessly attracting trouble. td. 105

Also –
Chan eil mòran aice mu a dhèidhinn. She doesn’t care much for him.

When used inside a negative construction (i.e. cha, nach, gun without), mòran generally connotes a small quantity (cf. beagan
few, little, modicum) and not just a ‘non-large’ quantity –
Cha do dh’òl Raonaid mòran uisge. Rachel didn’t drink much water. [She drank little water.]
Chan eil mòran leabhraichean aig Màiri. Mary doesn’t have many books. [She has few books.]
Thubhairt Kierkegaard riutha gu feumadh iad an leum amaideach a dheanamh ach ma bha duine aca ga thuigsinn cha robh móran airson an deuchainn sin a ghiùlain.
Kierkegaard said to them that they must take the leap of faith but if any of them understood him few wanted to undertake the experiment. td. 105
Chan eil móran Chrìosdaidhean cho dìleas rithe-se.
Few Christians are as faithful as her. td. 30
Bha fear na garaids [...] ag ràdh gu robh am Ford cho aosta ’s nach robh e furasta na pàirtean a bha air am milleadh a lorg. Cha robh e a’ dèanamh mòran strì airson am faighinn co-dhiù.
The mechanic said that the Ford was so old that it was not easy to find the parts that had been damaged. He wasn’t making much effort to get them anyway. td. 77

In addition, mòran can be used to emphasise a comparative adjective form –
Tha Seumas mòran nas beairtiche na Dòmhnall. James is much richer than Donald.
Bha e a’ ruith mòran na bu luaithe na Ted, agus leum e an gàrradh [...]
He was running much faster than Ted, and he jumped the fence [...] td. 81
